title: Survivors: Mid-run shop/inventory access from pause menu
description:
No way to spend gold, allocate skill points, or manage inventory during a run. All of that is only on the between-runs shop screen. For long runs (12+ min) this feels limiting.

Needs:
- Pause menu should have tabs/buttons for: inventory, skill tree, shop
- Or periodic shop breaks (e.g. every 3-5 minutes, like Vampire Survivors merchant)
- Show current gold, skill points, and equipped items on pause screen at minimum
- Consider a mid-run skill point allocation UI for points earned during the run
notes:
## Retro
- What worked: Reading the full engine.js upfront gave clear understanding of the pause system (HTML overlay), inventory/equipment system, and skill tree definitions. The existing patterns were consistent across all 4 themes, making bulk edits straightforward.
- What was unclear: The engine.js file was auto-committed by another process mid-edit, requiring careful detection of which changes still needed committing.
close_reason: Added tabbed pause menu with Inventory and Skills tabs. Inventory tab shows 3 equipped slots and inventory grid with equip/unequip/salvage actions. Skills tab shows full skill tree with point allocation. Header bar displays gold, skill points, and run time. All changes persist to localStorage and take effect immediately on resume via full stat recalculation.

title: Survivors: Chain weapon missing visual arc from player to first target
description:
The chain/arc weapon shows chain lines between bounced enemies but never renders the initial arc from the player to the first enemy hit. This makes it look like enemies are just dying randomly with no visual feedback connecting the player to the damage.

Also the chain weapon may be overtuned — it melts everything with the bounce scaling. Consider:
- Add visual arc/lightning line from player position to first enemy in chainHit()
- Review chain damage falloff (currently 0.8x per bounce) — may need steeper decay
- Review bounce count scaling (2 + level) — gets very high
- Review chain range scaling (150 + level*20) — covers huge area at high levels

File: games/survivors/engine.js, chainHit() function around line 861, and WEAPON_HANDLERS.chain around line 787
notes:
## Retro
- What worked: The existing chainLine effect between bouncing enemies was already well-structured, so reusing the same pattern for the player-to-first-enemy arc was a clean 4-line addition.
- What was unclear: Nothing major; the issue description was precise and pointed to the right lines.
close_reason: Added visual arc from player to first chain target

title: Fix survivors SFX volume balance vs audio tracker tracks
description:
The sound effects in the survivors game are 3-4x quieter than the audio tracker song playback. When background music tracks are added to survivors, the SFX will be drowned out.

Current state in engine.js:
- masterGain: 0.4
- SFX note volumes: 0.08-0.15
- SFX noise volumes: 0.1
- Ambient gain: 0.06

Need to either boost SFX volumes or add a separate music gain node that can be mixed lower relative to SFX. A dedicated music bus at ~0.25x the SFX level would let background tracks play without overwhelming gameplay sounds.
design: Add a musicGain node in the Audio module (engine.js) separate from the SFX path. Route background music through musicGain with a lower default (e.g. 0.1-0.15) while keeping SFX routed through the existing masterGain at 0.4. This gives independent volume control for music vs SFX.
acceptance_criteria:
- Background music plays at a level that does not overpower SFX
- SFX (weapon sounds, hit sounds, pickup sounds) remain clearly audible over music
- Volume balance feels natural during gameplay
- Music gain can be adjusted independently of SFX
notes:
## Retro
- What worked: Clear task spec made implementation straightforward. Adding a parallel gain bus without touching existing SFX routing was clean.
- What was unclear: Nothing significant - the task was well-defined.
close_reason: Added musicGain bus with independent volume control, setMusicVolume, getMusicGain, and mute integration

title: Survivors: Difficulty balance — skills + dash make it too easy
description:
Once you have a few permanent upgrades and the short-cooldown dash, the game becomes very easy. The cosmic level final boss area was the first time density felt meaningful, but by then the player is overpowered.

Areas to address:
- Dash cooldown may be too short, especially with utility_2 reduction
- Permanent upgrade scaling compounds too much (crit + lifesteal + multi-projectile + piercing)
- Early/mid game could use more pressure — enemies scale too slowly
- Consider difficulty tiers or NG+ scaling based on permanent upgrades owned
- Boss HP/damage may need scaling with player power level
notes:
## Retro
- What worked: Reading the full engine.js first gave a clear picture of all interconnected systems (dash, stats, spawning, boss attacks, save/progression). Surgical edits rather than rewrites kept changes contained.
- What was unclear: The exact balance feel is hard to judge without playtesting. The HP curve steepness and power-level scaling percentages may need further tuning based on player feedback.
close_reason: Rebalanced dash cooldown (1.2->1.6s base, utility_2 30%->18%, 50% cap), added stat soft caps (crit 60%, lifesteal 25%, multi-proj +3, piercing +3), steeper enemy HP curve with early-game speed boost, enemy/boss stats scale with player power level and world progression (NG+ 12%/world)

title: Set up Chrome DevTools MCP server in Termux
description:
Set up the official Google Chrome DevTools MCP server (chrome-devtools-mcp) to enable browser control from Claude Code on Android/Termux — screenshots, console error checking, JS evaluation, and network inspection.

## Steps

1. Install: `npx -y chrome-devtools-mcp@latest` — verify Node.js v20.19+
2. Enable Chrome remote debugging: `chrome://inspect/#remote-debugging` (Chrome 144+)
3. Test CDP port: confirm Termux can reach `localhost:9222`
4. Configure MCP in `~/.mcp.json`:
   ```json
   "chrome-devtools": {
     "command": "npx",
     "args": ["-y", "chrome-devtools-mcp@latest", "--browserUrl=http://127.0.0.1:9222"]
   }
   ```
5. Test: `take_screenshot`, `list_console_messages`, `evaluate_script`
6. If port 9222 doesn't work natively, try `--autoConnect` (Chrome 144+)

## References
- https://github.com/ChromeDevTools/chrome-devtools-mcp
- 26 tools: input, navigation, emulation, performance, network, debugging

title: Keyboard Guitar Hero — rhythm game using the sheet music renderer
description:
Build a Guitar Hero-style rhythm game where notes scroll toward a fixed playhead and the player hits keyboard keys to score points. The sheet music visualizer renderer already implements 90% of the visual mechanic.

## Concept

Notes scroll right-to-left on a grand staff, approaching a glowing cursor line. The player presses keys when notes cross the cursor to score hits. Accuracy windows (perfect/great/good/miss) determine points and combo multipliers. Could live in `games/` or as a mode within the visualizer.

## Existing Infrastructure

### Sheet Music Renderer (`music/visualizer/renderers/sheet-music.js`)
- Scrolling grand staff with treble + bass clefs
- Notes color-coded by channel (gold/rose/purple/silver → 4 lanes)
- Duration beams showing note length
- Glowing playhead at 15% from left edge
- Binary-search indexed timeline for efficient visible-note lookup
- `findFirst(rowThreshold)` already finds notes near the cursor
- Notes have `atCursor` detection (row <= currentRowFrac && noteEnd > currentRowFrac)

### Visualizer Engine (`music/visualizer/engine.js`)
- `frameData.cursor.totalFracRow` — precise fractional scroll position
- `frameData.analysis.timeline[row][ch]` — all note data pre-analyzed
- `frameData.analysis.channelRoles` — lead/harmony/bass/percussion per channel
- `frameData.currentNotes[ch]` — what's playing right now
- `frameData.analysis.rpb` — rows per beat for timing windows
- Song library of 57 songs at various difficulties

### Music Video Integration
The visualizer's music videos (`music/visualizer/music-videos/`) are self-contained HTML pages that load engine.js + playback-engine.js. A Guitar Hero mode could overlay on any video as a secondary canvas/UI, or be a standalone renderer. Frame callbacks (`Visualizer.addFrameCallback`) let secondary renderers subscribe to the same timing data.

## Design Considerations

- **Input mapping**: 4 channels → 4 keys (e.g., D/F/J/K or similar). Each channel is already color-coded.
- **Hit detection**: Compare key press time against note arrival at cursor. Use `analysis.secondsPerRow` to convert row distance to timing windows.
- **Scoring**: Perfect/Great/Good/Miss windows, combo multiplier, streak counter.
- **Visual feedback**: Note glow/flash on hit, miss animation, combo counter display, score overlay.
- **Difficulty**: Song BPM + note density naturally creates difficulty tiers. The song manifest has BPM data. Could auto-rate songs.
- **"Through the Fire and Flames" is the boss level**: High BPM + dense 4-channel patterns = maximum difficulty.
- **Could work as**: (a) a new visualizer renderer with input handling, (b) a standalone game page in `games/`, or (c) an overlay mode on music videos.

## Tech Notes

- Vanilla JS only, no frameworks (project rule)
- The sheet music renderer is an IIFE on `window.Renderers` — could fork it or extend it with a game layer
- `KeyboardEvent` listeners for input, `performance.now()` or `AudioContext.currentTime` for precise timing
- Consider mobile tap zones for touchscreen play (the project runs on GitHub Pages, mobile-friendly is a plus)
close_reason: Built full Rhythm Hero game at games/rhythm-hero/index.html with sheet-music note highway, 4-key input (D/F/J/K), timing-based scoring, combo system, particle effects, and animated results screen

title: The Lighthouse Keeper's Last Night — chiptune song + music video
description:
Compose a chiptune song and build a narrative music video for "The Lighthouse Keeper's Last Night."

**Story Arc**: A keeper tends a lighthouse on a stormy coast. Ships appear in distress. The storm intensifies. The light fails. He climbs the tower, repairs the mechanism by hand. The light reignites. Ships navigate safely past. Dawn breaks. He descends for the last time — he's being replaced by automation.

**Musical Direction**: D Dorian → storm chaos → triumphant repair → bittersweet major ending. Moderate tempo (~90-100 BPM). Should have room for environmental sound design (waves, wind, mechanical clock-like motifs for the lighthouse mechanism).

**Video Visuals**: Crashing waves with parallax layers, rain particles, rotating lighthouse beam cutting through fog, distant ship silhouettes, lightning flashes, interior stairwell climb scene. The lighthouse beam is the constant visual anchor — when it fails, the screen goes dark; when it reignites, the visual climax.

**Why it works**: One person vs. nature, a crisis/ordeal, triumph tinged with melancholy. Spiritual kin to Caravan of the Sirocco (solitary journey through hostile environment) with a bittersweet ending about obsolescence.
close_reason: Composed 3.1-minute chiptune song with 24 patterns, 628 events, 37 sequence entries. D Dorian clockwork motif through 12 narrative sections. Added to songs/index.json.

title: The Glassblower's Phoenix — chiptune song + music video
description:
Compose a chiptune song and build a narrative music video for "The Glassblower's Phoenix."

**Story Arc**: An artisan works in a forge, shaping molten glass. We watch the creation process — gathering, blowing, shaping. The piece shatters catastrophically at the crucial moment. Silence. Then she begins again, and this time the glass transforms into something alive — a phoenix that takes flight from the furnace into the night sky.

**Musical Direction**: Warm A major workshop warmth → building intensity → shattering dissonance → silence → rebuilding → transcendent Lydian climax. Tempo ~95-110 BPM. The shatter moment should be a dramatic musical rupture (channel dropout, noise burst), followed by genuine silence before the rebuild.

**Video Visuals**: Glowing orange/amber forge palette, molten glass particle effects, procedural glass-shaping animation, shatter burst with fragments, the phoenix as a rising constellation of embers against the night sky. The color arc goes warm amber → explosive white → dark silence → ember orange → blazing gold/white ascent.

**Why it works**: Creation/destruction/rebirth arc. The forge is the "hostile environment" like the desert. The shatter is the sandstorm/throne collapse moment. The phoenix transcends — the art becomes alive.
close_reason: Already shipped

title: The Cartographer of Drowned Cities — chiptune song + music video
description:
Compose a chiptune song and build a narrative music video for "The Cartographer of Drowned Cities."

**Story Arc**: A diver descends into a flooded ancient city, mapping it as she goes. Each district she explores triggers spectral memories — a market bustling, children playing, a temple ceremony. She reaches the deepest point: a sealed library. She opens it. The knowledge inside rises as luminous text through the water. She surfaces at dawn, her map complete, the city remembered.

**Musical Direction**: B Phrygian descent (like Oasis of the Forgotten King) → wonder → discovery → reverent climax → surfacing in warm major. Slow tempo ~80-88 BPM. Should feature layered arpeggios for the underwater feeling, with spectral memory sections using contrasting timbres (bright square wave "memories" against muted triangle "present").

**Video Visuals**: Underwater parallax with sunken architecture, bioluminescent particles, ghost-memory overlays (like Oasis's spectral court but as full scene flashbacks), rising text/glyph particles, depth gauge UI element. The descent/ascent mirrors Oasis but with an active mission (mapping) giving the traveler more agency.

**Why it works**: Direct spiritual successor to Oasis of the Forgotten King — underwater descent, spectral echoes of the past, but the cartographer has purpose and the ending is about preservation rather than loss. The rising text is the inverse of the Forgotten King's crumbling throne.
close_reason: Composed 3:14 song with 18 patterns in B Phrygian → B Lydian. 9-section narrative arc: Surface → Descent → Market/Children/Temple memories → Sealed Library → Knowledge Rising (climax with stretto + key shift) → Surfacing at Dawn → Map Complete. 7 instruments including detuned pipe, bright memory bell, and filtered underwater percussion.

title: Signal Fire on the Iron Mountain — chiptune song + music video
description:
Compose a chiptune song and build a narrative music video for "Signal Fire on the Iron Mountain."

**Story Arc**: A messenger runs through mountain passes carrying a torch to light a signal fire and warn a distant kingdom. Wolves in the forest. A collapsed bridge she must leap. Altitude sickness as she climbs above the clouds. She reaches the peak, lights the fire. Across the valley, another fire answers. Then another. A chain of fires across the horizon.

**Musical Direction**: Urgent E minor → forest darkness → bridge crisis → thin-air Lydian → blazing triumphant climax → quiet chain of distant fires. Fast tempo ~130-140 BPM to match the urgency of running. The tempo could thin out during the altitude section (fewer notes, more space), then explode at the fire-lighting.

**Video Visuals**: Side-scrolling runner through biome transitions (forest → bridge → snow → peak), torch as the constant warm element against cold/dark environments, wolf eyes glowing in darkness, the fire-lighting as the "breakthrough" moment, then a dramatic pullback to reveal the chain of signal fires answering across mountain silhouettes. Could use the stick-fight engine for the runner's animation.

**Why it works**: Forward momentum like Caravan of the Sirocco, environmental progression through biomes, a single point of light against darkness. The fire chain at the end is a deeply satisfying visual payoff — one person's effort rippling outward.
close_reason: Composed 20-pattern, 49-sequence, 782-event chiptune song at 132 BPM (~2:58). Narrative arc: E minor forest run → wolf chase → broken bridge → B Lydian thin-air → E major signal fire climax → chain of fires echo → horizon fade.

title: The Tide Clock — chiptune song + music video
description:
Compose a chiptune song and build a narrative music video for "The Tide Clock."

**Story Arc**: An old clockmaker on a coastal village builds a clock that tracks the tides. We watch seasons pass — spring tides bring fishing boats home, summer tides carry children swimming, autumn tides wash up strange artifacts, winter tides threaten to flood the village. The clock's pendulum syncs with the music's tempo. In the final sequence, the clockmaker passes the clock to his granddaughter as the tide goes out one last time.

**Musical Direction**: Gentle C major waltz (3/4 or 6/8 feel) → seasonal shifts in mode (spring Ionian, summer Lydian, autumn Mixolydian, winter Aeolian) → winter storm minor → resolution → tender passing-of-the-torch ending. Moderate tempo ~84-96 BPM. The pendulum tick should be a subtle rhythmic element throughout.

**Video Visuals**: Four distinct seasonal palettes (spring greens, summer golds, autumn ambers, winter blue-grays), rising/falling water line synced to music dynamics, clock mechanism gears as a visual motif overlaid or in foreground, village silhouette against changing skies, the granddaughter scene as a warm intimate close.

**Why it works**: Time passage as narrative arc, environmental storytelling through seasons, the tide as a visual metaphor for life's rhythms. More contemplative than the others — this is the "quiet epic." The generational handoff at the end gives it emotional weight without conflict.

title: Survivors: Enemy AI needs more aggression and variety
description:
Enemies mostly circle the player passively, especially in the cosmic level endgame. The density ramps up but since enemies dont move toward the player much, theres no pressure to dodge or reposition — sitting still works fine.

Needs:
- More enemy types that actively chase/charge the player
- Enemies that punish standing still (AoE telegraphs, converging patterns)
- Varied movement behaviors beyond circling (flanking, pincer, dive-bombers)
- Late-game elites with dangerous approach patterns
- Consider enemies that counter specific weapon types (dodge projectiles, resist area)
notes:
## Retro
- What worked: Clean separation of movement handlers made adding new types straightforward. The Pool/SpatialHash architecture supported the new behaviors without modification.
- What was unclear: Whether elite glow should be rendered by the engine or delegated to themes. Chose engine-side since it applies uniformly across all themes.
close_reason: Added flanker, divebomber, and shieldbearer enemy types with elite variants. All 4 themes updated with themed enemies. Base movement made more aggressive. Elite system triggers after 3 minutes.

title: Integrate audio tracker playback into survivors engine
description:
Add the ability for the survivors game to load and play chiptune tracker JSON songs as background music during gameplay.

title: Design 4 unique skill trees (one per class)
description:
Replace the single shared SKILL_TREE_DEF with per-class skill trees. Each class gets 3 branches x 4 nodes = 12 unique skills.

GUNNER (Cyberpunk):
- Precision: Crit chance → Crit damage → Headshot (instant kill <15% HP) → Overdrive (2x fire rate for 5s on kill streak)
- Arsenal: Multi-projectile → Piercing → Explosive rounds (AoE on hit) → Turret deploy (stationary auto-gun)
- Tech: Drone companion → Drone upgrade → Shield generator → EMP burst (stun all nearby)

DARK KNIGHT (Gothic):
- Blood: Lifesteal → Blood frenzy (attack speed on kill) → Thorns (reflect damage) → Death aura (constant AoE drain)
- Shadow: Summon skeleton → More summons → Skeleton mage → Army of darkness (mass summon burst)
- Undying: Regen → Damage reduction → Second life → Vampiric nova (heal burst when hit low HP)

RANGER (Forest):
- Nature: Poison DoT on hit → Spread poison → Root snare (slow enemies) → Overgrowth (poison zones on ground)
- Agility: Move speed → Evasion chance → Double dash → Phantom step (brief clone decoy on dash)
- Trapper: Bear trap (place on ground) → More traps → Trap damage up → Net launcher (AoE slow)

WARLOCK (Cosmic):
- Gravity: Pull enemies closer → Gravity well (vortex ability) → Mass increase (slow enemies) → Black hole (massive pull + damage)
- Time: CDR on abilities → Time slow bubble → Rewind (undo last 3s damage taken) → Temporal loop (repeat last ability free)
- Void: Ability power up → Void bolt (bonus magic projectile) → Void armor (DR scaling with ability power) → Singularity (ultimate AoE)

Files: engine.js (SKILL_TREE_DEF → CLASS_SKILL_TREES[classId]), all 4 shop pages (skill tree rendering), pause menu skill tab

- What worked: The Proxy pattern for SKILL_TREE_DEF backwards compatibility was clean and avoided touching any shop HTML files. The apply() function pattern on each node made the dynamic system straightforward.
- What was unclear: Nothing major - the task spec was very detailed and clear about which skills to implement and where they should hook in.

title: Survivors: Victory vacuum bug — level-up interrupts victory flow
description:
When the victory vacuum collects XP gems via addXp(), it can trigger a level-up which sets state to levelup. Dismissing the level-up card sets state back to playing instead of victory_vacuum, so the game continues indefinitely past the victory condition.

Partially fixed: addXp replaced with direct xp += in vacuum. But the level-up card dismiss handler (line 1248) should also be hardened to restore the pre-level-up state rather than always setting playing.

File: games/survivors/engine.js
close_reason: Fixed: vacuum now uses direct xp += instead of addXp to prevent level-up state override

title: Survivors: Inventory system — more slots, item management, salvage
description:
Currently limited to 3 equipped item slots with no way to manage inventory. Low-tier items accumulate with no purpose. Need a proper inventory system.

Needs:
- More inventory/equipment slots (or unlock additional slots via shop/progression)
- Inventory UI to view all collected items and swap equipped items
- Salvage/sell system for unwanted items (convert to gold or crafting materials)
- Item comparison when picking up loot (show stat diff vs equipped)
- Maybe item fusion: combine low-tier items into higher tier
notes:
## Retro
- What worked: Existing inventory CSS classes and equip/unequip pattern were well-structured, making it easy to extend with salvage and slot management
- What was unclear: The 4 shop pages having duplicated JS logic means every change needs 4x application; would benefit from shared script extraction in a future refactor
close_reason: Inventory system with swap, salvage, and expanded slots

title: Class system: unique skill trees, weapon affinities, and class abilities per theme
description:
Transform the 4 themes (Cyberpunk, Gothic, Forest, Cosmic) into distinct character classes. Currently all themes share identical skill trees (Offense/Defense/Utility with same 12 nodes), identical weapon types (all 8 available everywhere), and identical stat progression. The only difference is cosmetic naming/colors.

Each class should have:
1. A unique skill tree (3 branches, 4 nodes each) tailored to the class fantasy
2. Weapon affinities — 4-5 'primary' weapons that get bonus scaling, 2-3 'secondary' that are available but weaker
3. A class-specific ultimate/signature ability (replaces or augments one skill node)
4. Unique starting stats (speed vs HP vs damage tradeoffs)
5. Class-specific passive that defines playstyle

Proposed classes:
- Cyberpunk → Gunner: Projectile/beam focus, crit/piercing tree, drone companion ability
- Gothic → Dark Knight: Melee/AoE/chain focus, lifesteal/thorns tree, summon minions ability  
- Forest → Ranger: Boomerang/rain/field focus, speed/DoT/evasion tree, trap ability
- Cosmic → Warlock: Orbit/field/area focus, ability power/cooldown tree, gravity well ability

This addresses the core balance issue: currently getting lvl 5 main weapon + chain + damage upgrades trivializes everything because all classes converge on the same optimal build.
close_reason: Broken down into 6 subtasks: f16, b71, bi2, bga, 85o, obj

title: Add dual-format support to ChipPlayer.load()
description:
## Problem
The 4 survivors song files (survivors-*.json) are saved in the tracker native format but ChipPlayer.load() only accepts the compact format. This causes music to silently fail - song.seq is undefined so no notes schedule.

## Format Differences
- Tracker native: sequence, patterns[].channels (sparse event objects {r, n, i, d})
- ChipPlayer compact: seq, patterns[].ch (dense [midi, inst] arrays or null)

## Solution
Update ChipPlayer.load() in games/audio-tracker/playback-engine.js to detect and handle both formats. If song.seq exists use as-is (compact). If song.sequence exists normalize on the fly: sequence to seq, expand sparse channels into dense ch arrays, map instrument fields if needed.

This is preferred over re-exporting songs because new songs will keep getting saved in tracker-native format.

## Files to Modify
- games/audio-tracker/playback-engine.js - add format detection and normalization in load()

## Verification
1. Load any survivors arena (arena.html?world=cyberpunk) - music should play after game starts
2. Verify volume is reasonable (musicGain is 0.12 vs SFX master 0.4)
3. Test that compact-format songs still work
4. Test in organ.html and tracker that nothing breaks

## Context
- engine.js already has loadMusic/startMusic/stopMusic wired up
- Each theme file already declares song path
- arena.html already loads playback-engine.js before engine.js
- Music starts on startGame(), stops on victory/game over
close_reason: Dual-format support added to ChipPlayer.load() and campfire music wired into hub
